column2: officially Royal Town of Klang (Malay: Bandar Diraja Klang)
column3: is a royal town and former capital of the state of Selangor
column4: Malaysia. It is located within the Klang District. It was the civil capital of Selangor in an earlier era prior to the emergence of Kuala Lumpur and the current capital
column6: which is located in the Klang District
column7: is the 12th busiest transshipment port and the 12th busiest container port in the world.The Klang Municipal Council or MP Klang exercises jurisdiction for a majority of the Klang District while the Shah Alam City Council exercises some jurisdiction over the east of Klang District
column8: north of Petaling District and the other parts of Selangor State including Shah Alam itself.

column1: The royal town of Klang has been a site of human settlement since prehistoric times. Bronze Age drums
column2: axes and other artefacts have been found in the vicinity of the town and within the town itself. A bronze bell dating from the 2nd century BC was found in Klang and is now in the British Museum. Also found in or near Klang are iron tools called "tulang mawas" ("ape bones") and a bronze drum. Commanding the approaches to the tin rich Klang Valley
column3: Klang has always been of key strategic importance. It was mentioned as a dependency of other states as early as the 11th century. Klang was also mentioned in the 14th century literary work Nagarakretagama dated to the Majapahit Empire
column4: and the Klang River was already marked and named on the earliest maritime charts of Chinese Admiral Cheng Ho on his visits to Malacca from 1409 to 1433.

column1: Klang was under the control of the Malacca Sultanate in the 15th century.  The celebrated Tun Perak
column2: the Malacca's greatest Bendahara
column3: came from Klang and became its territorial chief. According to the Malay Annals
column4: the people of Klang overthrew the local chief or penghulu and asked the Sultan of Malacca Muzaffar Shah to appoint another
column5: and Tun Perak was then appointed the leader. Klang was known as a producer of tin; according to Manuel Godinho de Erédia
column6: it produced one hundred bares of tin a year when the Portuguese occupied Malacca.  Klang however remained in Malay hands after the fall of Melaka to the Portuguese in 1511
column7: and was controlled by the Sultan Johor-Riau. In the 17th century
column8: the Bugis began to settle in the coastal region of Selangor including Klang
column9: and the Selangor sultanate was created in the 1766

column1: In the 19th century the importance of Klang greatly increased by the rapid expansion of tin mining as a result of the increased demand for tin from the West. The desire to control the Klang Valley led directly to the Klang War (also called the Selangor Civil War) of 1867–1874 when Raja Mahdi fought to regain what he considered his birthright as territorial chief against Raja Abdullah. During the Klang War
column3: the seat of power was moved to Bandar Temasya
column4: Kuala Langat
column5: and then to Jugra which became the royal capital of Selangor.Klang however did not lose its importance.  In 1874
column6: Selangor accepted a British Resident who would "advise" the Sultan
column7: and Klang became the capital of British colonial administration for Selangor from 1875 until 1880 when the capital city was moved to Kuala Lumpur due to the growth of Kuala Lumpur from tin-mining. Today Klang is no longer State capital or the main seat of the ruler
column8: but it remains the headquarters of the District to which it gives it name.

column1: Until the construction of Port Swettenham (now known as Port Klang) in 1901
column2: Klang remained the chief outlet for Selangor's tin
column3: and its position was enhanced by the completion of the Klang Valley railway to Bukit Kuda in 1886
column4: which was then connected to Klang itself via a rail bridge
column6: completed in 1890.  In the 1890s its growth was further stimulated by the development of the district into the State' leading producer of coffee
column8: the royal seat was moved back to Klang when it became the official seat of Sultan Sulaiman (Sultan Alauddin Sulaiman Shah).

column2: a local authority
column3: known as Klang Health Board
column4: was established to administer Klang town.  The official boundary of Klang was first defined in 1895. The first road bridge over the Klang River connecting the two parts of the town
column6: was constructed in 1908. In 1926 the health boards of Klang and Port Swettenham were merged
column7: and in 1945 the local authority was renamed Klang Town Board. In 1954
column8: the Town Board became the Klang Town Council after a local election was set up to select its members in accordance with the Local Government Election Ordinance of 1950.  In 1963
column9: the Port Klang Authority was created and it now administers three Port Klang areas: Northport
column13: which incorporated the nearby townships of Kapar and Meru as well as Port Klang
column14: was formed. After undergoing a further reorganisation according to the Local Government Act of 1976 (Act 171)
column15: Klang District Council was upgraded to Klang Municipal Council (KMC) on 1 January 1977. From 1974 to 1977
column16: Klang was the state capital of Selangor before the seat of government shifted to Shah Alam in 1977.

column1: Klang may have taken its name from the Klang River which runs through the town. The entire geographical area in the immediate vicinity of the river
column2: which begins at Kuala Lumpur and runs west all the way to Port Klang
column3: is known as the Klang Valley.

column1: One popular theory on the origin of the name is that it is derived from the Mon–Khmer word Klong
column2: which may mean a canal or waterway. Alternatively it has also been argued that it means "warehouses"
column3: from the Malay word Kilang –  in the old days
column4: it was full of warehouses (kilang currently means "factory").Klang was also once known as Pengkalan Batu meaning "stone jetty".

column1: Klang is divided into North Klang and South Klang
column2: which are separated by the Klang River. North Klang is divided into three sub-districts which are Kapar (Located at the north of North Klang)
column3: Rantau Panjang (situated at the west of North Klang) and Meru (at the east of North Klang).

column1: Klang North used to be the main commercial centre of Klang

column3: more residential and commercial areas as well as government offices are being developed in Klang South. Most major government and private health care facilities are also located at Klang South. Hence
column4: this area tends to be busier and becomes the centre of social and recreational activities after office hours and during the weekends. This is triggered by the rapid growth of new and modern townships such as Bandar Botanic

column2: Port Klang was previously named Port Swettenham until 1972 when it was renamed Port Klang.

column1: Port Klang is located at Klang South.
The economy of Klang is closely linked with that the greater Klang Valley conurbation which is the most densely populated
column2: urbanised and industrialised region of Malaysia. There is a wide range of industries within the Klang municipality
column3: major industrial areas may be found in Bukit Raja
column4: Kapar
column6: Taman Klang Utama and Sungai Buloh
column8: Teluk Gong and others. Rubber used to be an important part of the economy of the region
column10: many rubber plantations have switched to palm oil
column11: and were then converted again for urban development and infrastructure use.Port Klang forms an important part of the economy of Klang.  It is home to about 95 shipping companies and agents
column14: as well as more than 70 freight and transport companies. It handled almost 50% of Malaysia's sea-borne container trade in 2013. The Port Klang Free Zone was established in 2004 to transform Port Klang into a regional distribution hub as well as a trade and logistics centre.

column1: Klang encompasses three parliamentary seats: Kapar (Mr. Manikavasagam a/l Sundaram of PKR)
column2: Kota Raja (Mr. Mohamad Sabu of Amanah)
column3: and Klang (Mr. Charles Anthony Santiago of DAP).  All three are held by the Pakatan Harapan coalition. These constituencies are subdivided into state seats.

column1: The following are the census figures for the population of Klang.  The 1957 and 1970 figures are for the Klang district and were collected before the reorganisation of Klang and the Bumiputra status being used as a category. The 2010 figures are for MP Klang.  The figure for Klang city is not given as what constitutes Bandar Klang appears to be inconsistent with considerable fluctuation in numbers over the years.
There are a number of criminal gangs operating in Klang
column2: and gang violence is not uncommon. Among the Chinese community
column3: there are the Ang Bin Hoey triad gangs such as Gang 21 which operates in Kuala Lumpur and the Klang Valley. There are also Gang 24
column4: Gang 36 and others
column5: and their members are often Indians. Due to economic development and changes in the industry
column6: many rubber estates where Indian plantation workers used to live and work were closed
column7: and this is thought to have contributed to a rise of gangsterism amongst the displaced and economically-deprived Indians. It is thought that the Indians originally worked for Chinese gang leaders but they now dominate many of these criminal organisations.

Smart Selangor Bus Programme was established by the Selangor State Government to provide an efficient and high quality free public transportation service to its citizen. This programme was launched in July 2015 starting with 3 local authorities but it was later expanded to all 12 local authorities in 2020 due to overwhelming response from the public. Selangor Intelligent Transport Systems Application (SITS) enables the Smart Selangor Bus users to plan their journey effectively and intelligently through the bus services available.

column1: The double-decked Kota Bridge was first built in late 1950s as a replacement for the Belfield Bridge. The double-decked bridge now closed to car traffic after a new Kota Bridge was built alongside it in the 1992

column3: bicycles and motorcycles. A second bridge in Klang
column4: the Musaeddin (Tengku Kelana) Bridge
column5: was built in the 1980s near the Kota Bridge. The RM199 million Klang Third Bridge was opened for traffic in May 2017
column6: complementing the existing two other road bridges in the city that connect Klang North and Klang South.

column1: The royal residence of the Sultan of Selangor was built in 1950 in south Klang to replace the old Mahkota Puri Palace. Parts of the Palace are accessible to the public but only on a few days of the week.
Near the Palace is the Klang Royal City Park (Taman Bandar Diraja Klang)
column2: and located in front of the Palace is a sports stadium (Stadium Padang Sultan Sulaiman) and the Royal Klang Club.

column1: The royal Mosque was built in 1932.

column2: Goddess of Mercy Temple)

column1: Kuan Im Teng (as pronounced in the Hokkien dialect) was established in 1892 and is over 100 years old. This Goddess of Mercy Temple is located at the Jalan Barat Daya
column2: near Simpang Lima. Bustling with devotees during the first day and the fifteenth day of lunar calendar. It is one of the oldest temple in Malaya since colonial period
column3: built by the Hokkien community.

column1: The temple is also involved in charity work
column2: contributing to several health and educational organisations.  On the eve of Chinese New Year
column3: the temple is opened all night and the street is often packed with devotees queuing shoulder to shoulder to enter the temple hall to offer their incense to the Kwan Yin in hope for an auspicious start to the New Year.

column1: A memorial erected to commemorate the Silver Jubilee of the Sultan of Selangor's installation in 1985. The monument is specially designed to depict the Keris Semenanjung that symbolises power

column1: The only temple in Malaysia dedicated to the worship of Justice Bao (包公)
column2: who was a government officer in ancient China's Song Dynasty. Justice Bao consistently demonstrated extreme honesty and uprightness and is today respected as the cultural symbol of justice in the Chinese community worldwide.
the Esplanade is a sea-side family recreation spot near to North port that houses several seafood restaurants. Nice setup for sunset-gazing and also for anglers to fish.

column1: Colourful street from the striking saris hanging from shops to the snacks and sweetmeats on sale from shops and roadside stalls. During Deepavali

column2: it is one of the oldest and the largest of the Vaishnavite temples in Malaysia. The temple is often referred to as the "Thirupathi of South East Asia" after its namesake in India.
Klang

column1: A Hindu temple devoted to the worship of Lord Murugan in Teluk Pulai
column2: Klang that was established on 14 February 1914. It holds a unique distinction among the Hindu temples in Klang as it was founded and managed by the Ceylonese/Sri Lankan community who lived around the vicinity of the temple. Prayer rituals are done like those in Sri Lanka and certain festivals specific to the Ceylonese/Jaffnese community are celebrated here. The arasamaram or sacred fig tree which is in the temple was there since 1914 and is possibly one of the oldest living tree in Klang.

column1: Is one of the oldest bridge in Malaysia's Klang Valley region. It was built in 1948 by the British. The bridge is located in Jalan Dato' Mohd Sidin (Federal route ) near Connaught Bridge Power Station in Klang Selangor.

column2: Connaught bridge can only be crossed one vehicle at a time. No lorry could pass it because it was limited to car
column3: van and small vehicle only. While on the bridge
column4: you will heard the sound of wood 'cracking'! The wooden bridge closed in 1993–1994. In 1995 the wooden bridge was replaced by a concrete box girder bridge.

column1: Is the first and only double-decker bridge in Malaysia and South East Asia. The bottom deck is a pedestrian walkway bridge while the top deck is a motorist bridge.  The bridge was closed to car traffic in the '90s due to high demand that necessitated the construction of a new bridge.
The new Jambatan Kota is located beside of the old bridge. The old bridge was constructed between 1957 and 1960
column2: and was officially opened in 1961 by the late Sultan of Selangor
column3: Almarhum Sultan Salahuddin Abdul Aziz Shah as part of the celebration of his coronation as the ninth Sultan of Selangor.

column1: Is the royal gallery located at Bangunan Sultan Suleiman
column2: Klang. Various collections depicting the reign of Sultan Salahuddin Abdul Aziz Shah; from his early childhood through his appointment as the eighth Sultan Selangor in 1960 and as the eleventh Yang di-Pertuan Agong in 1999.

Selangor Maritime Gateway’s (SMG) master plan covers 88
column2: 000 acres of land along 56 km of Klang River. This initiative ascertains the quality and opportunity of potential developments along the river. The project
column3: undertaken by Landasan Lumayan Sdn. Bhd. (a subsidiary of MBI Selangor) will be highly beneficial to the economy of the state. The master plan set-up reserves Klang as an Eco Smart City to spur on new sustainable social and economic growth along Klang River that includes elements of river cleaning
column4: rehabilitation & development. Sungai Klang will be turned into a new source of economy for the state through the Selangor Maritime Gateway (SMG) project. SMG includes several development components including commerce

column1: Landasan Lumayan Sdn Bhd (LLSB) has been given the mandate to clean the Klang River since 2016 crossing four municipalities namely MBPJ
column2: MPSJ
column3: MBSA and MPK. Due to the efforts given
column4: a vast amount of total waste collected until July 2019 is around 50
column5: 000 MT. The debris has been reduced from average of 1
column7: 094 MT per month in 2019. This enormous improvement is due to public awareness among the residents through various programs and activities organised under Selangor Maritime Gateway. Projects includes :

column1: Rehabilitation ensures the sustainability of the surrounding population and environment in a changing climate. The objectives are to restore ecological balance
column2: to improve water quality to avoid flood mitigation as well as to preserve the environment for a better transformation of Klang River. The primary purpose of rehabilitation of Telok Kapas with 98 acres of land in Pasir Panjang
column3: Klang which had been officially stopped in operation in 2007 is to improve water quality as well as restoring the site with a proper safe closure. The comprehensive rehabilitation of Klang River involves creation of new land and utility services with estimated cost of RM 3 billion that involve the Design Concept
column4: Construction and Operation and Maintenance. The objectives are to increase the water quality and economic activities.

column1: The framework sets to re-establish the urban developments along the river from one zone to the other. The plans set the development of six (6) zones in Selangor Maritime Gateway (SMG) through consolidation of Urban Design
column2: Landscape
column3: Transportation
column4: Environmental and Economic Consideration of the existing condition and cultural context. Six zones are proposed as a basis for creating community identity and place-making along the river stretch. Together
column5: the intention brings the true potential of what Klang River can be as well as gives a new pulse to the river. The catalyst projects includes :

column1: River Patrol Unit (PRU) was established to monitor any illegal activities that may risk water quality and it has been commenced at certain routes along Klang River. Apart from the physical impact project
column2: we have acted proactively by conducting continuous monitoring along the river reserves to ensure that no activity is at risk of polluting the Klang River. Therefore
column3: the formation of the Motorcycle River Patrol Unit is required at this point with the assistance of existing government agencies such as LUAS

column2: providing connectivity via water for tourist destinations along the river which brought a huge impact to the earlier population in terms of economic activities and growth of the Klang Valley.
